title: Andy Murray beats Stan Wawrinka to win first ATP singles final in over two years
text:
Murray beat Stan Wawrinka in a nervy final (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

Nine months after being retired on court by his peers, nine months after hip surgery, Andy Murray is once again an ATP champion after defeating Stan Wawrinka to win the European Open.

His career was supposed to be finished but Murray, arguably Britain’s finest ever sportsman, has never known when to lie down and accept defeat, and he has finally been rewarded with a first title in two-and-a-half years.

His fighting spirit, his unwillingness to be beaten was there for all to see. Down a set and a break and twice a point away from falling a double break behind, Murray rallied in the most dramatic fashion and beat a fellow three-time Grand Slam champion 3-6 6-4 6-4.

This is Murray’s first ATP Tour singles title since winning at Dubai in March 2017.

Stan Wawrinka was in good form (Picture: AP)

At the start of the year, Murray was in sheer agony even when attempting menial tasks such as putting his socks on but he is now pain free and thriving. Hope for the future is bright.

There is now no need to question whether he can resurrect his career. It’s alive. How high he can climb in 2020 will be a source of wonder for sports fans around the globe.

This title may not be as prestigious a win as a Grand Slam but this will surely rank among the most special victories in Murray’s illustrious career. From where he was at the start of the season, it’s scarcely believable.

For much of this battle in Antwerp, Wawrinka was the superior player.

His weaponry was firing on all cylinders, with Murray just keeping himself within touching distance in the hope that his level dipped.

Murray was pushed hard by Wawrinka (Picture: Getty)

The moment it did, Murray pounced. First to recover from a break down in the second set before pinching it, then on two separate occasions in a tense decider.

‘It means a lot. Last few years have been extremely difficult,’ an emotional Murray said after the match.

‘Both me and Stan have had a lot of injury problems in the last couple of years.

Murray was clearly emotional after the match (AP Photo/Francisco Seco)

‘It’s amazing to be back, playing against him in the final like that. I think it was a great match.

‘Stan was playing unbelievable. I just managed to hang in a bit at the end of the second set and the third set was extremely close again.

‘I didn’t expect to be in this position at all. I’m happy, very happy.’
